articleContent.title: Arpeggio: Dominant 7#5 in G# (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Arpeggio: Dominant 7#5 in G# (Shape: E)

## Brief Presentation
In music theory, an arpeggio refers to the playing of the notes of a chord in a sequence rather than simultaneously. The Dominant 7#5 arpeggio consists of the root (G#), major third (B#), augmented fifth (Dx), and minor seventh (F#) of a dominant 7#5 chord in G#. When utilizing the E shape on the guitar, this arpeggio provides a unique and dissonant sound that can add tension and color to your music.

## Notes and Intervals
- G# (Root)
- B# (Major Third)
- Dx (Augmented Fifth)
- F# (Minor Seventh)

| Note | Interval from Root |
|------|--------------------|
| G#   | Root               |
| B#   | Major Third        |
| Dx   | Augmented Fifth    |
| F#   | Minor Seventh      |

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7#5 arpeggio, with its augmented fifth, adds a sense of tension and dissonance to the music. It is commonly found in jazz, fusion, and progressive rock genres where musicians seek to introduce complex harmonies and extend the possibilities of chord progressions. The augmented fifth creates a unique sound that can be both jarring and intriguing, making it a versatile tool for adding color and complexity to compositions.

## Songs
1. **"Birdland" by Weather Report**: This jazz fusion classic features intricate chord progressions and arpeggios, including the Dominant 7#5 arpeggio, adding depth and complexity to the composition.
   
2. **"Bohemian Rhapsody" by Queen**: In this iconic rock opera piece, Queen incorporates various harmonic elements, including arpeggios, to create a rich and dynamic musical tapestry.
   
3. **"The Dance of Eternity" by Dream Theater**: Known for their complex and technically demanding music, Dream Theater showcases the Dominant 7#5 arpeggio and other advanced techniques in this progressive metal instrumental track.
